data: <(= Cerophytidae (part), Eucnemidae (part), Elateridae: Anischiinae)>

characters.name: <geographical distribution>
data: <The genus \i{}Anischia\i0{} is widely distributed throughout the warmer parts of the world. Species have been described from Central and South America, Africa and New Guinea, and unnamed species have been seen from Australia, New Caledonia, Fiji and the New Hebrides.>
<Artematopodines are restricted to tropical America, occurring from Nicaragua south to Brazil.>
<Macropogonines occur in North America, southern Europe and Asia.>
<\i{}Brachypsectra\i0{} has been recorded from Western North America, India, Malaysia and northwestern Australia.>
<Buprestidae is a cosmopolitan family.>
<Trachyines are widely distributed.>
<Schizopodinae are restricted to the southwestern part of North America.>
<Byrrhidae are almost entirely restricted to the temperate parts of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres.>
<Callirhipidae are widely distributed throughout the tropical and subtropical regions of the world.>
<Cantharidae is a cosmopolitan family.>
<Species of \i{}Cerophytum\i0{} occur from North to South America and in southern and central Europe.>

<\i{}Chelonarium\i0{} is common in the tropical and subtropical parts of the New World and eastern Asia to northern Australia, while \i{}Pseudochelonarium\i0{} is restricted to Southeast Asia and the East Indes.>

<Dascillidae occur in western North America, the West Indies, Eurasia, southern South America, Africa, southeastern Asia, the Sunda Archipelago and eastern Australia; they are not commonly collected.>
<Drilidae occur in southern Europe, Asia Minor, Africa and India.>
<Dryopidae occur in most parts of the world, including New Zealand, but they are absent from Australia.>
<Agrypnine elaterids are widely distributed.>
<Cardiophorine elaterids are widely distributed.>
<Cebrionines occur from North to South America, in southern Europe and North Africa, and in Southeast Asia; they appear to be most abundant in warmer, drier areas.>
<Denticollinae occur in most region of the world, but are more abundant and diverse in cool temperate areas.>
<Elaterinae is a more or less cosmopolitan group.>
<Lissominae occur in the southern United States, tropical America, the Palaearctic region, tropical Africa and Asia, New Guinea, New Zealand and Australia.>
<Species of \i{}Austrelater\i0{} are restricted to the eastern coast of Australia and Lord Howe Island.>
<Two species of \i{}Oestodes\i0{} occur in the northern part of North America.>
<Negastriinae occur in most regions of the world, but they are apparently absent in Australia.>
<\i{}Pityobius\i0{} species occur in North America, while \i{}Metablax\i0{}, \i{}Parablax\i0{} and their relatives inhabit New Zealand and Australia.>
<Thylacosternines are distributed from Mexico to South America, and in Africa, Asia, New Guinea and Australia.>
<Elmidae is a cosmopolitan family.>
<The Eucnemidae is a cosmopolitan family.>
<North America>
<\i{}Phyllocerus\i0{} species occur in southern Europe, Asia Minor, the Caucasus, Central Asia, South Africa and Madagascar.>
<\i{}Eulichas\i0{} occurs in southeast Asia and \i{}Stenocolus\i0{} is restricted to the west coast of North America.>
<Heteroceridae is a widespread family, but is absent from New Zealand.>
<Lampyridae are widely distributed in tropical and subtropical regions, but are much less common in cool temperate areas.>
<Limnichidae is a cosmopolitan family.>

<Species of \i{}Hyphalus\i0{} have been collected on Green and Heron Islands on the Great Barrier Reef, in coastal Queensland between Cairns and Rockhampton, on Lord Howe and Norfolk Islands, on the northeast coast of the North Island of New Zealand, and on the Cocos-Keeling Islands in the Indian Ocean.>
<\i{}Lutrochus\i0{} species are known from North and South America.>
<Lycidae are distributed throughout the world, mainly in tropical regions.>
<Omalisidae occur in Europe and Asia Minor.>
<Mastinocerine Phengodidae are widely distributed from North to South America.>
<Phengodini are distributed from North to South America.>
<Most species of \i{}Eubrianax\i0{} occur in the Old World, but one species is known from western North America and another from Peru.>
<Eubriine Psephenidae occur in most regions of the world.>
<Psephenines occur in North and South America and Asia.>
<\i{}Psephenoides\i0{} occurs in Asia, while \i{}Afropsephenoides\i0{} is known from Africa.>
<Anchytarsinae are widely distributed.>
<\i{}Araeopidius monachus\i0{} is restricted to he northwest coast of North America.>
<Species of Cladotominae occur in North America, Japan, Australia, South America and Madagascar.>
<Ptilodactylinae are widely distributed, but occur mainly in tropical and subtropical regions.>
<The species of \i{}Diplocladon\i0{} are known from India, Sumatra and Java.>
<Rhipiceridae occur in North and South America, southern Europe, North Africa, Asia Minor, eastern and southern Africa, Asia, Australia and New Caledonia.>
<Rhipiceridae occur in North and South America, southern Europe, North Africa, Asia Minor, eastern and southern Africa, Asia, Australia and New Caledonia.>
<Scirtidae is a widely distributed family, but the greatest diversity occurs in the temperate parts of the Northern and Southern Hemispheres.>
<Throscidae is a widely distributed family.>

characters.name: <biology and comments>
data: <Adults have been taken in flight intercept traps and by pyrethrum fogging trunks and logs; a larva and several adults were sifted from wood.>

<Larvae of \i{}Artematopus\i0{} were collected in the superficial layer of forest soil and reared through to the adult stage on termite workers and tenebrionid beetle larvae, which had been cut into pieces.>

<Larvae of \i{}Eurypogon\i0{} and \i{}Macropogon\i0{} have been found in mats of mosses on granitic boulders, while those of \i{}E. niger\i0{} (Melsheimer) were associated with the lichen \i{}Umbilicara\i0{}. The food source is uncertain, since the mouthparts include an efficient particle filter and the gut contained only very fine material.>

<\i{}Brachypsectra\i0{} larvae live under stones or loose bark or in rock crevices and are ambush predators of spiders or other small arthropods, which they pin between the flexible head and "tail" spine and pierce with their perforate mandibles.>

<The larvae of Buprestidae usually feed on the cambium and outer wood of trees and shrubs; most species attack weakened or dead plants, but some bark borers can kill healthy plants and wood-boring larvae may even damage timber. Leaf-mining and gall forming species also occur in the family, but most of these belong to the Trachyinae and are keyed out separately. North American pest species include the bronze birch borer, \i{}Agrilus anxius\i0{} Gory and the flatheaded apple tree borer, \i{}Chrysobothris femorata\i0{} (Olivier).>
<Larvae of Trachyini are leaf-miners.>
<Schizopodine larvae occur in the soil and feed on roots.>

<Most species of Byrrhidae feed as larvae and adults on the leaves and rhizoids of mosses and liverworts (Bryophyta), but some have been recorded from lichens and others are known to attack the roots of various angiosperms, including grasses.>
<Callirhipid larvae are relatively common in old logs, which have been attacked by white-rot fungi, so that the wood is punky and light in color.>

<Cantharid larvae are commonly found in leaf litter and soil, under stones, in moss and under bark; they are usually predacious and have been reported to feed on caterpillars and fly larvae. Some Holarctic larvae are known to be phytophagous, and it is possible that other species have a more varied diet.>
<Larvae of \i{}Cerophytum\i0{} have been recorded from old rotten wood, which was softened by fungi and dark in color.>

<Larvae of Chelonariidae have been collected in the root systems of orchids and other epiphytes, in leaf litter and forest debris, under bark and in the refuse heaps of leaf-cutting ants; they apparently feed on decaying plant matter.>

<Larvae of \i{}Dascillus\i0{} and probably most Dascillidae occur in the soil and may be collected beneath stones. They feed on plant roots and other organic matter in the soil, breaking food up with complex epipharyngeal and hypopharyngeal plates, similar to those found in Scarabaeoidea. At least some Karumiinae are associated with termites, but the larval feeding habits of these are unknown.>
<Larval drilids are predators of gastropods. Female Drilidae are more or less larviform, without elytra or wings, but with adult legs and antennae.>
<Dryopid larvae are most commonly found in damp soil, leaf litter and rotting vegetation; although they may inhabit riparian situations, no dryopid larvae are aquatic.>

<Agrypnine larvae usually occur either under bark or in rotten wood (e.g. \i{}Alaus\i0{}, \i{}Hemirhipidius\i0{}, \i{}Paracalais\i0{}) or in soil (e.g. \i{}Agrypnus\i0{}, \i{}Conoderus\i0{}). Predaceous habits are common, especially in the wood-inhabiting forms, but the soil-dwelling forms are often phytophagous, feeding on roots, tubers etc. Larvae are known as wireworms, and those of of various species of \i{}Conoderus\i0{} and \i{}Agrypnus\i0{} are pests of crops.>
<Larvae of Cardiophoprinae occur in the soil and are predacious.>
<Larvae of Cebrioninae live exclusively in the soil; their feeding habits are unknown.>

<Larvae may be found under bark or in rotten wood, in soil, or on the surfaces of rocks or logs among mosses and lichens; they are usually predacious. Larvae are known as wireworms, and those of some \i{}Ctenicera\i0{} and \i{}Limonius\i0{} are crop pests.>

<Elaterine larvae may be found in soil (e.g. \i{}Agriotes\i0{}, \i{}Dalopius\i0{}, \i{}Glyphonyx\i0{}) or under bark and in rotten wood (e.g. \i{}Ampedus\i0{}, \i{}Dicrepidius\i0{}, \i{}Elater\i0{}). Larvae are known as wireworms, and those of some \i{}Agriotes\i0{} are crop pests.>

<All known lissomine larvae occur under bark or in rotten wood, and the mouthpart structure suggests that they may be wood feeders; however Hudson (1934) observed the New Zealand \i{}Sphaenelater lineicollis\i0{} (White) attacking the larvae of tipulid flies.>
<Larvae have been found in white-rotten wood.>
<\i{}Oestodes\i0{} larvae occur in soil and are phytophagous.>
<Larvae of Negastriinae occur in soil.>
<Pityobiines occur under bark or in rotten wood and are predacious.>
<Known thylacosternine larvae have been found in dead wood; larvae of of \i{}Cussolenis mutabilis\i0{} were found with eucnemid larvae and pupae and one was seen to feed on a pupa.>

<All elmid larvae are fully aquatic, obtaining oxygen through the anal gills, which are extruded when the operculum is opened. They occur in a variety of habitats, but commonly inhabit shallow moving water, where they feed on algae, diatoms and decaying plant material among substrates of gravel and rock. Some species are commonly found on water-logged wood or among roots and moss at the stream edge.>

<Most eucnemid larvae occur in dead wood, but it is not certain what food source they utilize. The mouthparts are of a liquid-feeding type, but the mandibles are incapable of opposition, making predation unlikely. It is probable that the woody substrate is broken down extra-orally and the chemical products consumed.>

<The putative larva on which this description is based was taken from soil from either San Diego or San Ysidro, California. Both localities are on the label. This was collected on 1-4-65 by E. D. Algert and has the USDA number 65-1485, but also the number 4024 after San Ysidro,CA. There is also the number L.166on the label and the note "Family unc., poss. Elateridae. det. DMA" (= D. M. Anderson).>
<Larvae of \i{}Phyllocerus\i0{} occur in the soil among roots and rotting plants.>
<Eulichadid larvae occur in small streams or rivers, where they feed on decaying vegetation lying on the bottom or at the water's edge.>

<Larvae of Heteroceridae live in burrows in wet sand or mud along the banks of streams, ponds or other bodies of water; they feed on diatoms, algae and other organic material which is taken into the gut along with quantities of the substrate.>

<Lampyrid larvae usually occur in mesic environments, where they are found under rocks, in leaf litter, in vegetation bordering streams and ponds and in rotten logs. All larvae are predacious, feeding on gastropods, earthworms and other soft-bodied invertebrates. Prey is paralalyzed by secretions produced by glands attached to the alimentary canal and ejected through the perforate mandibles; digestion takes place extra-orally and only liquids are imbibed.>

<Limnichid larvae occur in a variety of habitats, but they are usually found near water. They may be found in leaf litter, damp soil or humus at the edges of streams or ponds or in the marine littoral zone burrowing in sand wetted by ocean spray. The larvae apparently feed on dead organic matter.>
<\i{}Hyphalus\i0{} larvae occur in the intertidal zone, where they live in crevices in rocks and beneath coral slabs. They appear to feed on the film of blue-green algae lining the rocks.>

<Larvae of \i{}Lutrochus\i0{} are aquatic and are known to burrow in travertine in shallow rapids or sometimes in rotten wood and feed on algae, diatoms and probably other organic matter. Oxygen is obtained through anal gills.>
<Lycid larvae occur in leaf litter and under bark, and they are thought to feed on soft, decaying plant material or possibly slime molds or yeasts.>
<Larvae of \i{}Omalisus fontisbellaquei\i0{} Fourcrouy occur in leaf litter and feed on millipedes of the genus \i{}Glomeris\i0{}.>

<Larvae of Mastinocerini inhabit leaf litter and are usually active at night. They are predators on other arthropods, including millipedes. Larvae and larviform females are bioluminescent; the head glows red, while the body has 11 pairs of greenish-yellow lights.>
<Larvae of Phengodini inhabit leaf litter and are usually active at night. They are predators on other arthropods, including millipedes.>

<\i{}Eubrianax\i0{} larvae feed on algae growing on rocks in streams; they are flattened and limpet-like and are thus are not swept away by the current. Air is obtained through ventral abdominal gill tufts.>

<Eubriine larvae feed on algae growing on rocks in streams; they are flattened and limpet-like and are thus are not swept away by the current. Air is obtained through anal gill tufts, which are extruded when the operculum is opened.>
<Psephenine larvae feed on algae growing on rocks in streams; they are flattened and limpet-like and are thus are not swept away by the current. Air is obtained through ventral abdominal gill tufts.>

<Psephenoidine larvae feed on algae growing on rocks in streams; they are flattened and limpet-like and are thus are not swept away by the current. Air is obtained through anal gill tufts, which are extruded when the operculum is opened.>
<Anchytarine larvae are primarily aquatic, feeding on rotting vegetation, such as leaves or dead wood, in streams; some species are riparian and occur among detritus along stream margins.>
<The larva of \i{}Araeopidius\i0{} occurs among gravel and detritus at the edges of small streams.>
<Cladotomine larvae are known from detritus along the margins of streams.>
<Larvae of \i{}Ptilodactyla\i0{} occur in leaf litter and rotten wood, and are entirely terrestrial.>
<\i{}Diplocladon\i0{} larvae occur in forest litter and are predators.>

<The only known rhipicerid larvae are those of \i{}Sandalus niger\i0{} Knoch, which occur in the soil and are ectoparasites of cicadas. The first instar is a triungulin, which hatches from eggs laid in cracks on the bark of trees.>

<The only known rhipicerid larvae are those of \i{}Sandalus niger\i0{} Knoch, which occur in the soil and are ectoparasites of cicadas. The first instar is a triungulin, which hatches from eggs laid in cracks on the bark of trees.>

<Larval Scirtidae are usually found in aquatic situations, normally in stagnant water, such as ponds, tree holes, marshes or bogs; however some larvae have been collected in damp rotting wood well away from water. They are detritus-feeders and have a complex filter-feeding mechanism for gathering and concentrating very small particles in liquid suspension. Enlarged terminal spiracles are used to obtain air at the water surface.>

<Larvae of the European \i{}Trixagus dermestoides\i0{} (Linnaeus) occur in the soil and feed on mycorrhizal fungi on roots, but several North American specimens have been found in decaying wood and grass tufts.>

states: not broadly ovate and strongly flattened
broadly ovate, strongly flattened and disc-like
characters.name: body <whether disc-like>

states: relatively straight or only slightly curved ventrally
characters.name: body <whether C-shaped>

states: elongate and more or less parallel-sided
characters.name: body, as viewed from above <shape>

states: consisting of fine hairs or setae only
including bristles, scales, expanded or complex hairs
characters.name: vestiture <type>

states: more or less heavily pigmented or sclerotized
characters.name: dorsal surfaces <pigmentation or sclerotization>

states: not concealed from above by prothorax
completely concealed from above by prothorax
characters.name: head <whether concealed by prothorax>

states: not forming sclerotized, serrate, wedge-like plate
characters.name: head <whether forming sclerotized, serrate, wedge-like plate>

states: not strongly depressed and wedge-like anteriorly
characters.name: head capsule <whether depressed and wedge-like>
posterior edge of head capsule <whether emarginate>

states: with longitudinal furrow (sometimes obscuring epicranial stem) for attachment of retractor muscle
characters.name: median epicranial region <whether with longitudinal furrow>

states: straight, not bent to the left
characters.name: epicranial stem <whether bent to the left>

states: not joined anteriorly by transverse line
characters.name: frontal arms <whether joined anteriorly>

states: not extending anteriorly to meet mandibular articulations, either incomplete or ending at antennal sockets
extending anteriorly to meet mandibular articulations
characters.name: frontal arms <whether meeting mandibular articulations>

states: absent or coincident with epicranial stem
Y-shaped, coincident with epicranial stem and frontal arms
moderately to very long, extending anterad of epicranial stem
short or long, extending between frontal arms (epicranial stem absent)
short or long, epicranial suture not evident
characters.name: median endocarina <position>

states: absent or coincident with frontal arms
characters.name: paired endocarinae <position>
ratio of antennal length to head width

states: apparently absent in antennae (usually 1- or 2-segmented) with apical sensorium
characters.name: sensorium(a) on preapical antennal segment <presence>

states: as long as or longer than apical segment
characters.name: sensorium(a) on preapical antennal segment <relative length>
sensorium(a) on preapical (or apical) antennal segment <shape>

states: truncate, so that sensorium and apical segment arise together
oblique, so that sensorium arises proximad of apical segment
characters.name: apex of preapical antennal segment <whether oblique>

states: by strip of membrane or cuticle narrower than antennal socket
by strip of cuticle between 1 and 2 times as wide as antennal socket
by strip of cuticle at least 2 times as wide as antennal socket
characters.name: antenna separated from mandibular articulation <distance>

states: separated from head capsule by complete suture
partly fused to head capsule (suture incomplete)
completely fused to head capsule (suture absent)
characters.name: labrum <attachment>

states: opposable, at least slightly curving mesally at apex
non-opposable, straight or curving laterally at apex
characters.name: mandibles <whether non-opposable>

states: not approximate, diverging and longitudinally divided
approximate at base and divided longitudinally so that 2 pairs of diverging blades or stylets are formed
characters.name: mandibles <whether forming diverging blades or stylets>

states: absent or fused to head capsule
flattened and more or less triangular
broad at base and narrow at apex
broad and stout or more or less wedge-like
elongate, deeply cleft and with apical teeth directed both laterally and mesally
characters.name: mandibles <shape>

states: with open or partly closed groove
characters.name: mandibles <whether grooved or perforate>

states: narrow when viewed from in front (parallel or oblique to plane of movement)
broad when viewed from in front (perpendicular to plane of movement)
characters.name: apex of mandible <orientation>
apex of mandible <number of lobes or teeth>

states: with brush of hairs or spines
with fixed, rigid, hylaline process, sometimes partly sclerotized
with 2 to 5 hyaline processes, sometimes joined basally
with mola or basal processing area
with brush of hairs and fixed, hyaline process
with brush of hairs and articulated process
with articulated process and membranous lobe
characters.name: mesal surface of mandibular base <whether simple>

states: without hyaline lobe or brush at base
with brush or hairs or spines at base
with hyaline lobe and brush of hairs at base
characters.name: mola <armature at base>

states: a rigid hyaline process, fixed or articulated, sometimes partly sclerotized
complex, consisting of 2 or more hyaline processes, a brush of simple or complex hairs, or a series of fringed membranes
a membranous lobe fringed with simple or complex hairs
a fixed, rigid process and brush of hairs
characters.name: prostheca <type>

states: narrow with acute or narrowly rounded apex
narrow with bifid or multidentate apex
broad at base and abruptly narrowed to acute apex
characters.name: prostheca or basal mandibular process <shape>

states: pubescent or serrate along one edge
characters.name: prostheca or basal mandibular process <vestiture>

states: separated from each other by labium
closely approximate or contiguous, not separated by labium
completely fused or combined with labium to form single plate
characters.name: cardines or maxillary bases <whether contiguous or fused together>

states: with articulated galea and fixed lacinia
characters.name: maxilla <number and articulation of lobes>

states: bearing 2 or 3 spurs or bifid spur
setose with 2 or 3 spurs or bifid spur
characters.name: apex of mala or galea <armature-vestiture>

states: with one to several small teeth
characters.name: inner apical angle of mala <whether with teeth or uncus>

states: bearing 2 or 3 spurs or bifid spur
characters.name: apex of lacinia <armature-vestiture>
number of segments in maxillary palp
first segment of maxillary palp <whether with digitiform appendage>

states: consisting of prementum, mentum and submentum
characters.name: labium <subdivision>

states: completely free or basally connate with maxillae
completely or almost completely connate with maxillae
partly or completely fused with maxillae (sutures incomplete or absent)
characters.name: mentum, postmentum or labial plate <degree of freedom>

states: subquadrate or trapezoidal, with blunt posterior edge
characters.name: postmentum or labial plate <whether subtriangular>
postmentum or labial plate <whether divided longitudinally>

states: as long as or longer than labial palp
characters.name: ligula <relative length>
number of segments in labial palp

states: contiguous or separated by less than width of first palp segment
separated by more than width of first palp segment
characters.name: labial palps <degree of separation>

states: consisting of a single sclerite shaped like a molar tooth (usually irregularly concave)
divided into 2 parts or consisting of more than 1 sclerite
characters.name: hypopharyngeal sclerome

states: moderately long but not extending to posterior edge of head
extending to posterior edge of head
long with 1 pair extending to posterior edge of head
characters.name: hypostomal rods <length>

states: with 1 pair diverging and another subparallel or slightly converging
characters.name: hypostomal rods <direction>
gula or gular region <whether fused to labium>

states: divided into 2 parts by tentorial bridge
characters.name: occipital foramen <whether divided>

states: not or only slightly wider than abdomen
characters.name: prothorax <whether wider than abdomen>

states: not longer than meso- and metathorax combined
longer than meso- and metathorax combined
characters.name: prothorax <whether longer than meso- and metathorax combined>

states: with patch(es) of asperities on metathorax only
with patch(es) of asperities on meso- and metathorax
with patch(es) of asperities on prothorax only
with patches of asperities on all segments
characters.name: thoracic terga <whether with patches of asperities>

states: without rows of asperities or carinae
with transverse row(s) of asperities (sometimes forming carinae) on metathorax only
with transverse row(s) of asperities (sometimes forming carinae) on meso- and metathorax
with transverse row(s) of asperities (sometimes forming carinae) on prothorax only
characters.name: thoracic terga <whether with rows of asperities>
meso- and metaterga <whether with sclerotized plates>

states: with 2 or more patches of asperities
with patch of asperities and rod-like sclerotisation
with transverse rows of asperities or carinae
characters.name: prosternum <armature>

states: separated by less than 1 basal coxal diameter
separated by 1 to 2 basal coxal diameters
separated by more than 2 basal coxal diameters
characters.name: mesocoxae or coxal lobes <degree of separation>

states: absent or represented by non-articulated lobes or processes
characters.name: thoracic legs <presence>
number of segments in mesothoracic leg
